title: 'Mum killed herself then dad died of a broken heart
text:

A comedian who lost his mum to suicide before his dad died weeks later has said making people laugh 'saved his life'.

Each time Marcus Tisson takes to the stage, the tragedy that brought him there is at the front of his mind.

Three years ago his mum Margaret unexpectedly took her own life by jumping in front of a train, tearing his family apart.

Just two months later his dad Winston, who had battled schizophrenia all his life, passed away of what Marcus believes was a broken heart.

His parents' deaths left the 40-year-old from East London with severe anxiety and PTSD, but he says comedy saved his life.

In the aftermath, Marcus of Bow, East London, decided to channel his grief into making people laugh.

He has shared his story for World Mental Health Day, and hopes he can help inspire others through difficult times.

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

Marcus said doing stand-up is therapeutic for him, and he tackles the tragedy head-on in his performances.

He runs a campaign encouraging others to open up about their mental health, and believes laughter can help get this crucial message across.

"Suicide ruined my family," he said.

"When my mum took her own life it was a big shock to everyone around her, there were no signs of it.

"She seemed happy, even in the days before she took her life, we were talking about her birthday.

"That's what really hurts. If someone is ill you can prepare yourself and say goodbye, but to go like this, there are no words to describe it. I will never get over it."

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

Marcus last spoke to Margaret, who was 58 when she died, the day before her death - and desperately wishes she had spoken to someone about what she was going through.

"I just wish she had reached out and spoken to someone," he said.

"We could have helped her through it."

On August 21, 2016, the worst day of Marcus' life, he received a call from his aunt breaking the tragic news that his mum had died at Mile End station.

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

The tragedy, and his dad's death soon after, left him reeling, anxious about showing his grief to his young children and unable to leave his home.

"I had really bad anxiety and PTSD," he said.

"I didn't want to be around my children, I didn't want them to see me broken."

Marcus, who teaches speech, language and literacy in a school, had long harboured a dream of going into comedy.

"Comedy saved my life," he said. "It sounds strange, but it helps my anxiety.

"I always wanted to be a comedian, I was always the class clown, but taking to the stage is very different. It's like therapy to me."

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

He started by cautiously going up onstage at an open mic night and telling a few jokes.

"Once I get my first laughs I was OK," he said.

He gave his first solo show, named Don't Call Me Crazy, at the start of October in London, and has more events lined up, including a set in Edinburgh.

"I want to be international," he said.

"I want to travel around the world and take this message about mental health.

"I was a bit worried about using my mental health as comedy, I don't want people to thinking I'm laughing at mental health, but I'm telling my truth, I'm telling my story.

"I talk about my parents, I talk about my own anxieties."

(Image: Marcus Tisson)

And Marcus said he has had positive feedback from people who say his comedy resonates with them.

"It's a daily struggle, I have to take it day-by-day," he said.

"I know that my parents would want me to strive and carry on making people happy and inspired."

Marcus has set up a voluntary campaign group, Don't Suffer In Silence , and gives talks to businesses and schools to provide valuable help.

He also holds regular walks in East London's Victoria Park, and wants to help provide a support network for people with mental health issues.

Marcus said: "I'm not a professional, I'm not a counsellor, but I can send people to the right places.

"I think I'm making my parents proud."

* Samaritans (116 123) operates a 24-hour service available every day of the year. If you prefer to write down how you’re feeling, or if you’re worried about being overheard on the phone, you can email Samaritans at jo@samaritans.org
description: EXCLUSIVE: Marcus Tisson, of Bow, East London, was devastated when mum Margaret, 58, took her own life and dad Winston died two months later, but believes spreading laughter can help others through the pain
